Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the function of the copulatory plug
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most fascinating structures related to reproduction is the copulatory plug, a solidified mass derived from male seminal fluid that forms in the female reproductive tract shortly after mating. This structure occurs in most sexually reproducing animals, including many reptiles, birds, insects, rodents, and primates, yet its function remains poorly characterized. To address this gap in knowledge, a mouse model engineered with a defective copy of transglutaminase IV (Tgm4), a gene necessary for copulatory plug formation will be investigated. Preliminary data show that males who cannot form a copulatory plug suffer severe fertility defects; the main goals of this project are to figure out where reproductive failure occurs.

This research also has broader impacts on the surrounding community. Teachers and students from local inner city (Los Angeles) high schools will be incorporated into our scientific pursuits. A one week long Workshop on Molecular Evolution, a "hands on science" experience that guides participants from initial hypothesis, to experimental design and data collection, analysis and interpretation, and finally to publication will be a part of this project. In addition to collecting data necessary for this project, the Workshop will simultaneously demystify the scientific process and the university environment for high school students and teachers alike.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this research project was to understand the function of the copulatory plug, which forms shortly after mating when seminal fluid coagulates. Copulatory plugs are ubiquitous in the animal kingdom, but their function was not well understood. We leveraged a genetically engineered mouse that is missing one important seminal fluid gene (transglutaminase IV) and cannot form a copulatory plug. These males are normal in every way measured, they simply cannot form a copulatory plug. By comparing the reproductive success of males that can form a plug to those who cannot, we showed that males unable to form a plug suffer fertility defects. 

The intellectual merit of this research is that we have shown that the copulatory plug has multiple functions. For the first time, we definitively demonstrated that one male’s copulatory plug inhibits another male’s reproductive success. But even under non-competitive conditions, the copulatory plug plays an important role in fertilization outcomes. Specifically, when a male cannot form a copulatory plug, he has difficulties siring litters even though he successfully fertilizes oocytes. We are pursuing the hypothesis that the defects arise at the implantation stage, whereby females block implantation when they mate with males that fail to form a plug. This opens up an entirely novel experimental approach, and some of our future research plans include characterization of the initial shifts in female brain activity that leads to shifts in hormonal profiles required for normal pregnancy. Along the way, this grant funded six large publications in peer-reviewed journals, each representing a major advance in knowledge. Six different graduate students were involved in this research, four of which have earned their Ph.D. and are now making their own contributions to science.

If our research is to have broader impacts, we must engage the younger generation in the process of hypothesis testing. During this grant, we focused on local students from Los Angeles public high schools. We created a weeklong Summer Workshop on Molecular Evolution, where students as well as their teachers were invited into the lab for “hands-on” science. We worked in collaboration with the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County to collect tissue samples from different species of rodents that naturally do not form a copulatory plug. We then extracted DNA and sequenced various genes with the goal of identifying a molecular explanation for lack of plugs in these species. Importantly, the students experienced the scientific process from the ground up, from hypothesis formation to experimental design to data collection and inference. Multiple students from these workshops went on to university education, all were first-generation. 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Matthew Dean
